content:
Has anyone considered weakening the idea of an [[exponential ring]] so that the ring RRR of exponents is different than the ring R′R'R′ of numbers? That would allow finite fields to be nontrivial examples, e.g. R′=ZpR' = \mathbb{Z}_pR′=Zp​ and R=Zp−1.R = \mathbb{Z}_{p-1}.R=Zp−1​. Are exponential rings and finite fields the only nontrivial examples of such a structure?

Given a unital commutative ring RRR, how would I go about enumerating those rings R′R'R′ such that there exists a surjective monoid homomorphism E:R→R′∗E:R\to R'^*E:R→R′∗ such that for all x,y∈Rx, y \in Rx,y∈R, E(x+y)=E(x)E(y)?E(x+y) = E(x)E(y)?E(x+y)=E(x)E(y)? Maybe Sage or something?

Given any two rings R,R′R,R'R,R′ such that RRR is an exponential ring, and given a monoid homomorphism ρ:(R′,+)→(R,+)\rho:(R',+) \rightarrow (R,+)ρ:(R′,+)→(R,+), define rr′=rρ(r′)r^{r'}=r^{\rho(r')}rr′=rρ(r′). Then r0=rρ(0)=r0=1r^0=r^{\rho(0)}=r^0=1r0=rρ(0)=r0=1 and rr1′+r2′=rρ(r1′+r2′)=rρ(r1′)+ρ(r′2)=rρ(r1′).rρ(r2′)r^{r'_1+r'_2}=r^{\rho(r'_1+r'_2)}=r^{\rho(r'_1)+\rho(r'2)}=r^{\rho(r'_1)}.r^{\rho(r'_2)}rr1′​+r2′​=rρ(r1′​+r2′​)=rρ(r1′​)+ρ(r′2)=rρ(r1′​).rρ(r2′​) so that you get the kind of structure you're interested by.
Probably, it provides a functor between two appropriate categories.
Interesting, this looks like a change of base functor
ah, I was about to write that as well ;-)
Yes, I was thinking to that indeed :) (the change of base)
adjoint to the forgetful from expoRing to Ring?
but you need a homomorphism.. hm

It makes me think to a more categorified concept. Consider a (finitary) distributive monoidal category (C,⊗,I,×,⊤)(\mathcal{C},\otimes,I,\times,\top)(C,⊗,I,×,⊤) (it is a kind of categorified semi-ring). Then an exponential functor !:C→C!:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}!:C→C is a strong monoidal functor (C,×,⊤)→(C,⊗,I)(\mathcal{C},\times,\top) \rightarrow (\mathcal{C},\otimes,I)(C,×,⊤)→(C,⊗,I)
This little guys appear in math and in logic

In linear logic, you ask for !!! to be a comonad and more. There is also the notion of relative monad when !!! would be between different categories. And there is still to invent the notion of relative linear logic. It makes me think to that because it is somehow the same move than going from exponential ring to relative exponential ring (let me call your concept by this name).

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Given any two rings R,R′R,R'R,R′ such that RRR is an exponential ring, and given a monoid homomorphism ρ:(R′,+)→(R,+)\rho:(R',+) \rightarrow (R,+)ρ:(R′,+)→(R,+), define rr′=rρ(r′)r^{r'}=r^{\rho(r')}rr′=rρ(r′). Then r0=rρ(0)=r0=1r^0=r^{\rho(0)}=r^0=1r0=rρ(0)=r0=1 and rr1′+r2′=rρ(r1′+r2′)=rρ(r1′)+ρ(r′2)=rρ(r1′).rρ(r2′)r^{r'_1+r'_2}=r^{\rho(r'_1+r'_2)}=r^{\rho(r'_1)+\rho(r'2)}=r^{\rho(r'_1)}.r^{\rho(r'_2)}rr1′​+r2′​=rρ(r1′​+r2′​)=rρ(r1′​)+ρ(r′2)=rρ(r1′​).rρ(r2′​) so that you get the kind of structure you're interested by.

Thanks! Hmm, it looks like you swapped which ring has the prime on it. I'll restate using BBB for base ring, EEE for exponents ring, and μ\muμ for monoid homomorphism:

Given any two rings E,BE, BE,B such that BBB is an exponential ring, and given a monoid homomorphism μ:(E,+)→(B,+)\mu:(E,+) \rightarrow (B,+)μ:(E,+)→(B,+), define be=bμ(e)b^{e}=b^{\mu(e)}be=bμ(e). Then b0e=bμ(0e)=b0b=1b^{0_e}=b^{\mu(0_e)}=b^{0_b}=1b0e​=bμ(0e​)=b0b​=1 and be1+e2=bμ(e1+e2)=bμ(e1)+μ(e2)=bμ(e1)⋅bμ(e2)b^{e_1+e_2}=b^{\mu(e_1+e_2)}=b^{\mu(e_1)+\mu(e_2)}=b^{\mu(e_1)}\cdot b^{\mu(e_2)}be1​+e2​=bμ(e1​+e2​)=bμ(e1​)+μ(e2​)=bμ(e1​)⋅bμ(e2​) so that you get the kind of structure you're interested by.

Any exponential ring BBB comes equipped with a monoid homomorphism exp⁡(−):(B,+)→(B,⋅)\exp (-): (B, +) \to (B, \cdot)exp(−):(B,+)→(B,⋅); it's usually of the form b−b^-b− for some bbb in B.B.B. And you're pointing out that you can extend that with any other monoid homomorphism μ:(E,+)→(B,+)\mu: (E, +) \to (B, +)μ:(E,+)→(B,+) to get a relative exponential ring bμ(−)b^{\mu(-)}bμ(−). Nice!

I suppose we can do something similar on the other side: given a monoid homomorphism ν:(B,⋅)→(C,⋅)\nu: (B, \cdot) \to (C, \cdot)ν:(B,⋅)→(C,⋅), we get a relative exponential ring ν(b−):(B,+)→(C,⋅)\nu(b^-): (B, +) \to (C, \cdot)ν(b−):(B,+)→(C,⋅) so ν(b0)=ν(1b)=1c\nu(b^0) = \nu(1_b) = 1_cν(b0)=ν(1b​)=1c​ and

ν(bb1+bb2)=ν(bb1⋅bbb2)=ν(bb1)⋅cν(bb2).\nu(b^{b_1 +_b b_2}) = \nu(b^{b_1}\cdot_b b^{b_2}) = \nu(b^{b_1}) \cdot_c \nu(b^{b_2}). ν(bb1​+b​b2​)=ν(bb1​⋅b​bb2​)=ν(bb1​)⋅c​ν(bb2​).

Similar pre- and postcomposition lets us create relative exponential rings from other relative exponential rings.

Do all nontrivial relative exponential rings factor through either a nontrivial exponential ring or a finite field?

My definition of relative exponential ring above also included the requirement that the exp⁡\expexp homomorphism should be onto (B,⋅)(B, \cdot)(B,⋅) so that every nonzero element has a logarithm, but I guess that's not standard for exponential rings.

Mike Stay said:

Do all relative exponential rings factor through either an exponential ring or a finite field?

I don't know... For now I think we should organize all the structure, it looks like there are a few functors in sight! I'll don't include the onto requirement first.

I will consider that ring means "nontrivial ring"

So:

  • Let's denote U+:Ring→MonU_{+}:Ring \rightarrow MonU+​:Ring→Mon the functor which sends a ring RRR to the underlying additive monoid.
  • Denote U×:Ring→MonU_{\times}:Ring \rightarrow MonU×​:Ring→Mon the functor which sends a ring RRR to the underlying multiplicative monoid R\{0}R \backslash \{0\}R\{0} of RRR.
• An exponential ring is a tuple (R,exp)(R,exp)(R,exp) where RRR is a ring and exp:U+(R)→U×(R)exp:U_{+}(R) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)exp:U+​(R)→U×​(R) a monoid homomorphism.
• A relative exponential ring is a tuple (B,R,μ)(B,R,\mu)(B,R,μ) where BBB and RRR are rings and μ:U+(B)→U×(E)\mu:U_+(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(E)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(E) is a monoid homomorphism.
Now, what we said before looks easy... It's just a matter of composing monoid homomorphisms.
We can still define morphisms of relative exponential rings:
A morphism from (B1,R1,μ1)(B_1,R_1,\mu_1)(B1​,R1​,μ1​) to (B2,R2,μ2)(B_2,R_2,\mu_2)(B2​,R2​,μ2​) is given by a pair (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) of monoid homomorphisms such as below:
Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-2.29.59-PM.png
Of course there is the morphism (id,id)(id,id)(id,id) from (B,R,μ)(B,R,\mu)(B,R,μ) to itself and we can also compose morphisms:
Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-2.34.37-PM.png
So that we get a category RelExpRingRelExpRingRelExpRing (whether we include the epi condition or not)

• You ask whether each relative exponential ring (with the epi condition) μ:U+(B)↠U×(R)\mu:U_+(B) \twoheadrightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)↠U×​(R) is of the form:
    (1) U+(B)↠expU×(B)⟶mU×(R)U_+(B) \overset{exp}{\twoheadrightarrow} U_{\times}(B) \overset{m}{\longrightarrow} U_{\times}(R)U+​(B)↠exp​U×​(B)⟶m​U×​(R)
    or
    (2) U+(B)⟶mU+(R)↠expU×(R)U_+(B) \overset{m}{\longrightarrow} U_+(R) \overset{exp}{\twoheadrightarrow} U_{\times}(R) U+​(B)⟶m​U+​(R)↠exp​U×​(R)
for some exponential ring expexpexp and monoid homomorphism mmm
Well, well, well, I think we should introduce "logarithm rings"
• Let's say that a logarithm ring is a tuple (R,log)(R,log)(R,log) where RRR is a ring and log:U×(R)→U+(R)log:U_\times(R) \rightarrow U_+(R)log:U×​(R)→U+​(R) is a monoid homomorphism
• (We could as well introduce relative logarithm rings)

• Let's say that an exp/log ring is a tuple (R,exp,log)(R,exp,log)(R,exp,log) where RRR is a ring, exp:U+(R)→U×(R)exp:U_+(R) \rightarrow U_\times(R)exp:U+​(R)→U×​(R) and log:U×(R)→U+(R)log:U_\times(R) \rightarrow U_+(R)log:U×​(R)→U+​(R) are monoid homomorphisms such that
    log;exp=1U+(R)log;exp=1_{U_{+}(R)}log;exp=1U+​(R)​ and exp;log=1U×(R)exp;log=1_{U_{\times}(R)}exp;log=1U×​(R)​.
• (We could as well introduce relative exp/log rings)

Proposition: If (R,exp,log)(R,exp,log)(R,exp,log) is an exp/log ring then any relative exponential ring μ:U+(B)→U×(R)\mu:U_{+}(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(R) can be decomposed under the form:
Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-3.20.58-PM.png
so that it comes from the exponential ring (R,exp)(R,exp)(R,exp)

Proposition: If (B,exp,log)(B,exp,log)(B,exp,log) is an exp/log ring then any relative exponential ring μ:U+(B)→U×(R)\mu:U_{+}(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(R) can be decomposed under the form:
Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-3.26.06-PM.png
so that it comes from the exponential ring (B,exp)(B,exp)(B,exp)
It doesn't answer your question, but I think we've done some good progress into structuring the framework. I'll stop now for a bit
I'm still excited by this question. I can refine a bit what I wrote above.

• Define an exp;logexp;logexp;log ring to be a tuple (R,exp,log)(R,exp,log)(R,exp,log) where exp:U+(B)→U×(B)exp:U_+(B)\rightarrow U_\times(B)exp:U+​(B)→U×​(B) and log:U×(R)→U+(R)log:U_\times(R)\rightarrow U_+(R)log:U×​(R)→U+​(R) are two monoid homomorphisms such that exp;log=1U+(B)exp;log=1_{U_+(B)}exp;log=1U+​(B)​

• Define a log;explog;explog;exp ring to be a tuple (R,exp,log)(R,exp,log)(R,exp,log) where exp:U+(B)→U×(B)exp:U_+(B)\rightarrow U_\times(B)exp:U+​(B)→U×​(B) and log:U×(R)→U+(R)log:U_\times(R)\rightarrow U_+(R)log:U×​(R)→U+​(R) are two monoid homomorphisms such that log;exp=1U×(B)log;exp=1_{U_\times(B)}log;exp=1U×​(B)​
Then, the above propositions become:

Proposition: If (B,exp,log)(B,exp,log)(B,exp,log) is an exp;logexp;logexp;log ring then any relative exponential ring μ:U+(B)→U×(R)\mu:U_{+}(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(R) comes from the exponential ring (B,exp)(B,exp)(B,exp)

Proposition: If (R,exp,log)(R,exp,log)(R,exp,log) is a log;explog;explog;exp ring then any relative exponential ring μ:U+(B)→U×(R)\mu:U_{+}(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(R) comes from the exponential ring (R,exp)(R,exp)(R,exp)

So if we want to find a relative exponential ring μ:U+(B)→U×(R)\mu:U_{+}(B) \rightarrow U_{\times}(R)μ:U+​(B)→U×​(R) which doesn't come from an exponential ring, we need at least that:
(1) BBB can't be equipped with any structure of an exp;logexp;logexp;log ring
(2) RRR can't be equipped with any structure of a log;explog;explog;exp ring
Example: for every ring RRR, if we denote ϵ1:R→R\epsilon_1:R \rightarrow Rϵ1​:R→R the constant function equal to 111, then (R,ϵ1)(R,\epsilon_1)(R,ϵ1​) is an exponential ring.

Proof: ϵ1(0)=1\epsilon_1(0)=1ϵ1​(0)=1 and ϵ1(r+r′)=1=1.1=ϵ1(r).ϵ1(r′)\epsilon_1(r+r')=1=1.1=\epsilon_1(r).\epsilon_1(r')ϵ1​(r+r′)=1=1.1=ϵ1​(r).ϵ1​(r′) so that ϵ1:U+(R)→U×(R)\epsilon_1:U_+(R)\rightarrow U_\times(R)ϵ1​:U+​(R)→U×​(R) is a monoid homomorphism
Example: for every ring RRR, if we denote ϵ0:R→R\epsilon_0:R \rightarrow Rϵ0​:R→R the constant function equal to 000, then (R,ϵ0)(R,\epsilon_0)(R,ϵ0​) is a logarithm ring.

Proof: ϵ0(1)=0\epsilon_0(1)=0ϵ0​(1)=0 and ϵ0(r.r′)=0=0+0=ϵ0(r)+ϵ0(r′)\epsilon_0(r.r')=0=0+0=\epsilon_0(r)+\epsilon_0(r')ϵ0​(r.r′)=0=0+0=ϵ0​(r)+ϵ0​(r′) so that ϵ0:U×(R)→U+(R)\epsilon_0:U_\times(R)\rightarrow U_+(R)ϵ0​:U×​(R)→U+​(R) is a monoid homomorphism

But (R,ϵ1)(R,\epsilon_1)(R,ϵ1​) can never be made into a log;explog;explog;exp ring or an exp;logexp;logexp;log ring because, then we would have that RRR if of cardinal 111 and thus trivial. Same for (R,ϵ0)(R,\epsilon_0)(R,ϵ0​).

Example
If q=pkq=p^{k}q=pk where k≥1k \ge 1k≥1 and ppp is a prime number, then we have the finite field GF(q)GF(q)GF(q). There always exists what we call a primitive element: an element m∈GF(q)m \in GF(q)m∈GF(q) which is a generator of the group (GF(q)\{0},×)(GF(q)\backslash \{0\}, \times)(GF(q)\{0},×). Let mmm be a primitive element of GF(q)GF(q)GF(q). We then have a group homomorphism
logm:(GF(q)\{0},×)→(Z/(q−1)Z,+)log_m:(GF(q) \backslash \{0\},\times) \rightarrow (\mathbb{Z}/(q-1)\mathbb{Z},+)logm​:(GF(q)\{0},×)→(Z/(q−1)Z,+)
such that if we define the group homomorphism
logm:(Z/(q−1)Z,+)→(GF(q)\{0},×)log_m:(\mathbb{Z}/(q-1)\mathbb{Z},+) \rightarrow (GF(q) \backslash \{0\},\times)logm​:(Z/(q−1)Z,+)→(GF(q)\{0},×) by
expm(k)=kmexp_m(k)=k^mexpm​(k)=km
then (GF(q),Z/(q−1)Z,expm,logm)(GF(q),\mathbb{Z}/(q-1)\mathbb{Z},exp_m,log_m)(GF(q),Z/(q−1)Z,expm​,logm​) is a relative exp/log ring.
There is also the example of the matrices
Maybe matrices over Z/nZ\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}Z/nZ or something similar would provide a relative exponential ring which doesn't come from an exponential ring or a finite field
Thanks!
I just wanted to say: @Mike Stay this a very interesting idea, and @Jean-Baptiste Vienney fantastic, well done: very cool observations about expexpexp and logloglog rings here.

I have done work on exponential rings before, but also with the added assumption of working with a differential exponential ring, so an exponential ring (R,exp)(R,exp)(R,exp) with a derivation D:R→RD: R \to RD:R→R such that D(exp(x))=exp(x)D(x)D(exp(x)) = exp(x)D(x)D(exp(x))=exp(x)D(x) (think of this as the chain rule for ef(x)e^{f(x)}ef(x)

Now won't the function exp:R→R[[x]]exp: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} [[x ]]exp:R→R[[x]], where the codomain is the ring of formal powers series, where exp(x)=∑xnn!exp(x) = \sum \frac{x^n}{n!}exp(x)=∑n!xn​ be a relative exponential ring?

Now of course, R\mathbb{R}R is an exponential ring -- so maybe not the example you are looking for. But this should work for any commutative ring RRR where you can divide by 1n!\frac{1}{n!}n!1​

In fact, if you take the cofree diferential ring over any ring RRR, which is called the Hurwitz ring H(R)H(R)H(R) (and very similar to power series), I belive you always get a relative exponential ring R→H(R)R \to H(R)R→H(R) as described in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404998000991

(I am absolutely love Hurwitz rings! so happy to talk more about them if this seems like a relevant example)

JS PL (he/him) said:

Now won't the function exp:R→R[[x]]exp: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} [[x ]]exp:R→R[[x]], where the codomain is the ring of formal powers series, where exp(x)=∑xnn!exp(x) = \sum \frac{x^n}{n!}exp(x)=∑n!xn​ be a relative exponential ring?

I'm confused: the formal variable xxx isn't an element of R\mathbb{R}R.

JS PL (he/him) said:

In fact, if you take the cofree diferential ring over any ring RRR, which is called the Hurwitz ring H(R)H(R)H(R) (and very similar to power series), I belive you always get a relative exponential ring R→H(R)R \to H(R)R→H(R) as described in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022404998000991

(I am absolutely love Hurwitz rings! so happy to talk more about them if this seems like a relevant example)

OK, the Hurwitz ring H(R)H(R)H(R) consists of countable sequences of elements of R,R,R, and the derivation is a shift operator. The elements are very similar to the list of coefficients from a formal power series. And the map R→H(R)\mathbb{R} \to H(\mathbb{R})R→H(R) taking 0 to (1,0,0,...)(1, 0, 0, ...)(1,0,0,...) and r≠0r \ne 0r=0 to the series an=rna_n = r^nan​=rn (so that the resulting ring element is basically exp⁡(rx)\exp(rx)exp(rx)) gives a relative exponential ring, since exp⁡((r+s)x)=exp⁡(rx)exp⁡(sx)\exp((r+s)x) = \exp(rx) \exp(sx)exp((r+s)x)=exp(rx)exp(sx) in H(R).H(\mathbb{R}).H(R). Nice!

I think Faà di Bruno's formula should make H(R)H(\mathbb{R})H(R) into an exponential ring in its own right.

But well in any case, as R\mathbb{R}R is an exp;log ring with the above terminology, a relative exponential ring exp:(R,+)→(R[[x]]\{0},×)exp:(\mathbb{R},+) \rightarrow (\mathbb{R}[[x]]\backslash \{0\}, \times)exp:(R,+)→(R[[x]]\{0},×) comes necessarily from the exponential ring R\mathbb{R}R followed by a morphism of multiplicative monoids through the factorization (R,+)→expR(R\{0},×)(\mathbb{R},+) \overset{exp_{\mathbb{R}}}{\rightarrow} (\mathbb{R} \backslash \{0\}, \times) (R,+)→expR​(R\{0},×) →logR(R,+)→exp(R[[x]]\{0},×) \overset{log_{\mathbb{R}}}{\rightarrow} (\mathbb{R},+) \overset{exp}{\rightarrow}(\mathbb{R}[[x]] \backslash \{0\},\times)→logR​(R,+)→exp(R[[x]]\{0},×)
However, with a more exotic ring RRR, it could gives a solution to your problem
In the same way, taking R=GF(q)R=GF(q)R=GF(q), we will get the same kind of factorization
Maybe a morphism of monoids exp:(Z,+)→(H(Z)\{0},×)exp:(\mathbb{Z},+) \rightarrow (H(\mathbb{Z}) \backslash \{0\}, \times)exp:(Z,+)→(H(Z)\{0},×) would work

Mike Stay said:

JS PL (he/him) said:

Now won't the function exp:R→R[[x]]exp: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} [[x ]]exp:R→R[[x]], where the codomain is the ring of formal powers series, where exp(x)=∑xnn!exp(x) = \sum \frac{x^n}{n!}exp(x)=∑n!xn​ be a relative exponential ring?

I'm confused: the formal variable xxx isn't an element of R\mathbb{R}R.

Yes quite right, it should be instead exp(r)=∑rnxnn!exp(r) = \sum \frac{r^nx^n}{n!}exp(r)=∑n!rnxn​

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Maybe a morphism of monoids exp:(Z,+)→(H(Z)\{0},×)exp:(\mathbb{Z},+) \rightarrow (H(\mathbb{Z}) \backslash \{0\}, \times)exp:(Z,+)→(H(Z)\{0},×) would work

I don't think you need to remove 000. (unless you really want your logloglog factorization

Maybe it can help: the only exponential morphisms on Z\mathbb{Z}Z are f(n)=1f(n)=1f(n)=1 and f(n)=(−1)nf(n)=(-1)^nf(n)=(−1)n. Indeed, if fff is an exponential morphism, then f(0)=f(−1).f(1)=1f(0)=f(-1).f(1)=1f(0)=f(−1).f(1)=1, therefore f(1)f(1)f(1) is a unit, ie f(1)=±1f(1)=\pm 1f(1)=±1 and moreover f(n)=f(1)nf(n)=f(1)^nf(n)=f(1)n if n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 and f(−n)=f(−1)n=f(1)−nf(-n)=f(-1)^n=f(1)^{-n}f(−n)=f(−1)n=f(1)−n if n≤−1n \le -1n≤−1.
More generally if RRR is any exponential ring, then f(1)f(1)f(1) is a unit and f(n)=f(1)nf(n)=f(1)^nf(n)=f(1)n for every n∈Zn \in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z.
Are you not assuming that exp(0)=1exp(0) = 1exp(0)=1?
Thanks, corrected
Yes, we assume this

Right so just as a sanity check for myself, what are the exponentials e:Z→Ze: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}e:Z→Z with e(n+m)=e(n)+e(m)e(n+m) = e(n) + e(m)e(n+m)=e(n)+e(m) and e(0)=1e(0) = 1e(0)=1

Well for n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, we get that e(n)=e(1+...+1)=e(1)...e(1)=e(1)ne(n) = e(1+ ... + 1) = e(1) ... e(1) = e(1)^ne(n)=e(1+...+1)=e(1)...e(1)=e(1)n, so e(n)=e(1)ne(n) = e(1)^ne(n)=e(1)n
and similarly e(−n)=e(−1+...+−1)=e(−1)...e(−1)=e(−1)ne(-n) = e(-1 + ... + -1) = e(-1) ... e(-1) = e(-1)^ne(−n)=e(−1+...+−1)=e(−1)...e(−1)=e(−1)n, so e(−n)=e(−1)ne(-n) = e(-1)^ne(−n)=e(−1)n

So eee is completely determined by e(1)e(1)e(1) and e(−1)e(-1)e(−1).

Now we also have that 1=e(0)=e(1−1)=e(1)e(−1)1=e(0) = e(1 - 1) = e(1) e(-1)1=e(0)=e(1−1)=e(1)e(−1), but in Z\mathbb{Z}Z the only possibilities of xy=1xy =1xy=1 are x=y=1x=y=1x=y=1 or x=y=−1x=y=-1x=y=−1

So we must have e(1)=e(−1)=1e(1) = e(-1) = 1e(1)=e(−1)=1, which implies that e(x)=1e(x) = 1e(x)=1 for all x∈Zx \in \mathbb{Z}x∈Z
Or we must have e(1)=e(−1)=−1e(1) = e(-1) = -1e(1)=e(−1)=−1, which implies that e(x)n=(−1)∣x∣e(x)^n = (-1)^{\vert x \vert}e(x)n=(−1)∣x∣ for all x∈Zx \in \mathbb{Z}x∈Z
But the relative exponential Z→Z[[x]]\mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}[[x]]Z→Z[[x]] mapping a→∑anxnn!a \to \sum \frac{a^n x^n}{n!}a→∑n!anxn​ does not factor through the exponentials on Z\mathbb{Z}Z
How do you prove this?

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Mhh, I've been thinking to something. I think it is worth mentionning that for every exp ring RRR, every element e(x)e(x)e(x) of the image of the exponential is a unit since e(−x+x)=e(0)=1=e(x)e(−x)e(-x+x)=e(0)=1=e(x)e(-x)e(−x+x)=e(0)=1=e(x)e(−x). And so we always get a factorization (R,+)→(R×,×)→(R,×)(R,+) \rightarrow (R^{\times},\times) \rightarrow (R,\times)(R,+)→(R×,×)→(R,×) of the exponential as a composition of two monoid homomorphism, through the group of units.

I think it is better to define an exponential and a relative exponential by writing the domain as (R\{0},×)(R \backslash \{0\}, \times)(R\{0},×) if we want the above factorization to be a factorization through an exponential ring. Because here R×R^{\times}R× is never a subring of RRR, unless when RRR is trivial (because it needs to contain 000).

However, it could happen that S=R×∪{0}S=R^{\times} \cup \{0\}S=R×∪{0} is a subring of RRR. For instance if RRR is a field (but in this case the above factorization is trivial). But also, if we consider R=k[x]R=k[x]R=k[x] where kkk is a field, then S=kS=kS=k which is a subfield of RRR.

In that case the factorization is a factorization through a relative exponential ring: (R,+)→(S\{0},×)→(R\{0},×)(R,+) \rightarrow (S \backslash \{0\}, \times) \rightarrow (R \backslash \{0\}, \times)(R,+)→(S\{0},×)→(R\{0},×)
If we consider R≠0R \neq 0R=0, then a ring such that SSS is a subring is exactly "a nontrivial ring such that the sum of two units is either zero or a unit"
It sounds a lot like the definition of a local ring which is "a nontrivial ring such that the sum of two non-units is a non-unit" but this is not the same

On mathsatckexchange, someone asked the question how to name such a ring and someone else answered that we could name such a ring "a good ring" but the guy who answered asks the question whether good rings are useful or not.
It looks like a condition a bit stronger than asking RRR to be an algebra over a field (in the case that RRR is commutative, since it then makes SSS a field )

The way you did it above. If RRR is an integral domain, then (R\{0},×)(R \backslash \{0\}, \times)(R\{0},×) is a well-defined monoid. Then you ask that log:(R\{0},×)→(R,+)log: (R \backslash \{0\}, \times) \to (R,+)log:(R\{0},×)→(R,+)
